front: What are the four fundamental characteristics of a data communications system?
back: Delivery, Accuracy, Timeliness, and Jitter.

front: In data communications, what does 'delivery' mean?
back: Data must be delivered to the correct destination — the intended device or user only.

front: Define 'jitter' in data communications.
back: Variation in packet arrival time, which can affect quality in real-time applications like video.

front: Name the five components of a data communications system.
back: Message, Sender, Receiver, Transmission medium, and Protocol.

front: Differentiate between simplex, half-duplex, and full-duplex communication.
back: Simplex: one-way only. Half-duplex: both directions but not simultaneously. Full-duplex: both directions simultaneously.

front: What are the three main network criteria?
back: Performance, Reliability, and Security.

front: What is the difference between point-to-point and multipoint connections?
back: Point-to-point has a dedicated link between two devices. Multipoint shares a single link among multiple devices.

front: Give a one-line difference between LAN, MAN, and WAN.
back: They differ by geographic scope: LAN (small area), MAN (city/metro), WAN (large/global).

front: What is a 'protocol' in data communications?
back: A set of rules that govern data communications between devices.

front: List two examples of transmission media mentioned.
back: Twisted-pair wire and fiber-optic cable.

front: What is the definition of a network topology?
back: The physical or logical arrangement of network devices and connections.

front: Name two common physical topologies.
back: Bus and Star.

front: Explain how a bus topology operates.
back: All devices share a single communication line; signals are broadcast to all devices.

front: What is one advantage of a star topology over a bus topology?
back: Failure of one link does not affect others.

front: What is one disadvantage of star topology?
back: If the central hub fails, all devices are disconnected.

front: Compare bus and ring topology in terms of fault tolerance.
back: Ring fails completely if one link breaks; bus can still function if fault is isolated.

front: Which topology is easiest to install and why?
back: Bus, because it requires less cable and is simple to set up.

front: Give an example where ring topology might be preferred.
back: When predictable performance and orderly access to the medium are required.

front: How does a mesh topology provide reliability?
back: It offers multiple redundant paths between devices.

front: If you had to design a topology for a mission-critical system, which would you choose and why?
back: Mesh topology — provides redundancy and fault tolerance.

front: What does OSI stand for?
back: Open Systems Interconnection.

front: How many layers are in the OSI model?
back: Seven.

front: List the OSI layers from top to bottom.
back: Application, Presentation, Session, Transport, Network, Data Link, Physical.

front: Which OSI layer is responsible for routing?
back: Network layer.

front: Which OSI layer handles error detection and correction?
back: Data Link layer.

front: What is the role of the Transport layer?
back: Provides reliable data transfer, flow control, and error handling.

front: Differentiate between Physical and Data Link layers.
back: Physical transmits raw bits; Data Link organizes bits into frames and ensures error-free delivery.

front: Which OSI layer establishes, manages, and terminates sessions?
back: Session layer.

front: How would you explain the OSI model to a non-technical person?
back: A step-by-step system where each layer has a specific job to ensure communication works.

front: Evaluate: Is the OSI model practical for real-world networking?
back: Yes for understanding, but most real-world protocols use a hybrid like TCP/IP.

front: What does TCP/IP stand for?
back: Transmission Control Protocol / Internet Protocol.

front: Name the four layers of the TCP/IP model.
back: Application, Transport, Internet, Network Access.

front: Which TCP/IP layer corresponds to the OSI Network layer?
back: Internet layer.

front: What is the main function of TCP?
back: Provides reliable, ordered, error-checked delivery of data.

front: What is the main function of IP?
back: Provides logical addressing and routing.

front: How does UDP differ from TCP?
back: UDP is connectionless, faster, but less reliable than TCP.

front: Give an example where UDP is preferred.
back: Live streaming or gaming where speed is more important than reliability.

front: What is the loopback IP address?
Why is TCP/IP considered more practical than OSI?
back: It is based on real protocols in use and is widely implemented.

front: Propose a simple analogy for TCP/IP communication.
back: Like sending letters through a postal system where addresses and delivery rules are standardized.

front: Define bandwidth.
back: The maximum rate at which data can be transmitted over a network path.

front: Define throughput.
back: The actual rate of successful data transfer.

front: What is latency?
back: The delay between sending and receiving data.

front: Explain jitter in terms of latency.
back: The variation in latency over time.

front: Why is high bandwidth not always equal to high throughput?
back: Throughput can be reduced by errors, congestion, and protocol overhead.

front: How can latency affect user experience?
back: High latency can cause noticeable delays, making interactions sluggish.

front: Compare propagation delay and transmission delay.
back: Propagation delay is signal travel time; transmission delay is time to push all bits onto the link.

front: What factor primarily affects propagation delay?
back: The medium's physical properties and distance.

front: How would you improve throughput in a congested network?
back: Increase bandwidth, optimize protocols, or reduce network load.

front: Evaluate: Is jitter more critical in video conferencing or email?
back: Video conferencing, because timing consistency affects quality.

front: What is multiplexing?
back: Combining multiple signals for transmission over a single medium.

front: Name two common multiplexing techniques.
back: Frequency Division Multiplexing (FDM) and Time Division Multiplexing (TDM).

front: How does FDM work?
back: Assigns different frequency bands to different signals.

front: How does TDM work?
back: Assigns different time slots to different signals.

front: What is statistical TDM?
back: Allocates time slots dynamically based on demand.

front: Compare FDM and TDM in terms of efficiency.
back: TDM can be more efficient when users have bursty traffic.

front: Where is Wavelength Division Multiplexing used?
back: In fiber-optic communications.

front: Why use multiplexing?
back: To maximize the use of a communication channel's capacity.

front: Apply: Which multiplexing technique is best for continuous analog signals?
back: FDM.

front: Create: Design a simple TDM frame for 4 devices each sending 1 byte.
back: Frame would have 4 time slots, each 1 byte long, assigned in order to devices 1–4.
